description: Fixed version with factory validation for pair addresses
attack_scenario: 1) Attacker created fake token contracts mimicking legitimate addresses. 2) Created malicious pair contract with manipulated reserves (e.g., 1 fake token = 1000 real tokens). 3) Called router swap function with path through fake token. 4) Router accepted fake pair without factory validation. 5) Executed swap at manipulated price. 6) Extracted $7M in real tokens.
root_cause: Router accepts any pair address without validating it came from the official factory. Attacker can inject fake pairs with manipulated reserves.

transformation.fix_description: Added IFactory interface, factory state variable, constructor to set factory, and validation that pair address matches factory.getPair() result.

exact_changes.version_a: interface IFactory { function getPair(...) external view returns (address); }

address pair = factory.getPair(path[i], path[i+1]);
require(pair != address(0), "Pair does not exist");

transformation.why_fix_works: Factory validation ensures only legitimate pairs from the official factory can be used, preventing fake pair injection attacks.
